block.p: ''Mr. Clinton's Disbarment Case'' (editorial, May 25) argues unpersuasively that justice for President Clinton consists of ''no more, no less'' than what another lawyer would receive for similar conduct.

But Mr. Clinton is no ordinary lawyer. He is a lawyer of formidable understanding who oversees the Justice Department, with all its prosecutorial powers. He occupies a special position of public trust as president. His misconduct and his subsequent rationalizations have done far more damage to the nation than any small-town lawyer who steals money from a client.

''Mr. Clinton's Disbarment Case'' (editorial, May 25) argues unpersuasively that justice for President Clinton consists of ''no more, no less'' than what another lawyer would receive for similar conduct.

But Mr. Clinton is no ordinary lawyer. He is a lawyer of formidable understanding who oversees the Justice Department, with all its prosecutorial powers. He occupies a special position of public trust as president. His misconduct and his subsequent rationalizations have done far more damage to the nation than any small-town lawyer who steals money from a client.
When Arkansas judges review this case, they should take into account the greater responsibility that Mr. Clinton carries by virtue of his high office.
